text: Members of the Columbia Triathlon Club train by bicycling around the polygonal path shown.

Pentagonal Path

They start at vertex A and go on to vertices B, C, D, and E. Then they return to A and start another lap. At each vertex the cyclists have to make a left turn through an exterior angle of the polygon.

•What is the sum of the left-turn exterior angles that the cyclists make on one full lap? Explain how you can determine an answer without measuring. Then, measure the exterior angles to check your thinking.

The sum of the turn angles will be equal to 360°.

If we walk around a pentagon like the one given, we will end up facing in the same direction that we started in. We will have turned a full circle.

So, we need to test if ∠ A + ∠ B + ∠ C + ∠ D + ∠ E is equal to 360˚.

∠ A + ∠ B + ∠ C + ∠ D + ∠ E

∠ 40˚ + ∠ 75˚ + ∠ 85˚ + ∠ 65˚ + ∠ 95˚ = 360˚

More Polygonal Paths

•Draw several other polygons, including a triangle, quadrilateral, and hexagon.

•Is the angle you turn at each point as you walk around these polygons the same as that for a pentagon? Explain.
The angle that you turn can be different for each exterior angle of each polygon.
•Find the sum of the turn angles if you cycle around each figure and return to your starting point.
The sum of the turn angles is always 360˚ for any triangle, quadrilateral, pentagon, and hexagon.
